page.title: 17MAKING CIDER IN ST VEEP
page.content: Several farms in the area still make{cider}in the traditonal way. In autumm fallen{apples}are gathered from local orchards and taken to the cider houses. The apples are tipped into an{apple mill}which reduces them to a fine pulp. The pulp is then shovelled onto a layer of straw in the{cider press.}This is repeated, each time the ends of the straw are turned in, over the pulp. When it is 1.25m high, this{cheese,}as it is called, is pressed. Several men are usually needed to help turn the screw, and this strenuos work causes a thirst which is slaked by cider from an earlier making. {Apple juice}runs from the bottom of the press, which is then poured into {barrels}and left to{ferment.}When it considered ready, it can be drunk.
